PROJECT DESCRIPTION
VCS Version 3, CCB Standards Second Edition
This forest type plays a pivotal role in the livelihoods of many resource-poor rural communities who have
low domestic earnings (Mapaure & Ndeinoma, 2010). Thus, in addition to providing goods and services
for improvement and maintenance of livelihoods of the people, this forest type also plays an important
ecological role.
1.3.4.4Munga woodland
Munga woodlands, a variant of Savannah woodland, is usually associated with flat topography but may
occur in patches or most commonly along streams. Soils are alluvial of riverine origin with high Base
Exchange Capacity. These are usually sandy clays. The widepresence of Vachellia polycantha, V. seyal,
V. nigrescens, V. gerrardi, V. sieberiana, Albizia harvey, Combretum obovatum, V. tortilis, Piliostigma
thorningii, Combretum ghasalence, Kirkia acuminata, Loncocarpus capassa, Ziziphus abyssinica, Ficus
sp., and Lannea stuhlmannii typifies this vegetation type. Hyparrhenia sp., Andropogon sp., Panicum sp.,
Setaria sp., and Cymbopogon sp grass cover dominates the herbal layer. As expected, most farming
activities in the area are associated with this vegetation formation. It is also very important vegetation for
biodiversity.
1.3.4.5Riparian vegetation
This vegetation occurs along the riverine ecosystems in the project area. This vegetation type occurs
mainly on alluvial soils and annually flooded areas. It is important vegetation for biodiversity in the project
site. The common plant species that dominate this vegetation type include Trichlia emetica, Diospyros
mespiliformis, Garcinia livingstoneii, Termitalia sp., Salix subserrata, Hyphaene ventricosa, Combretum
imberbe, Xeroderris stuhlmannii, and Oncoba spinosa, Other plant species are mostly dominated by
wetland species mainly, Phragmites mauritianus, Pistea stratiotes, Echinochloa sp., Cyperus sp.,
Acroceras sp., Papsalum, Panicum sp., Setaria sphacelata, Penisetum sp., Cynodon dactylon, Imperata
sp., andChlorissp.Riparian forests and termitaria provide important microhabitatsfor small mammals.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION
VCS Version 3, CCB Standards Second Edition
The Musokotwane REDD+ proponent is Zambruss Enterprises Limited, an entirely private
company established in 2009 under the laws of the Republic of Zambia. Zambruss owns logging
concession in the area.The logging concession area covers about 13,000 ha, though it has never
been active.
In line with the Musokotwane REDD+ project, Zambruss will perform the following key project
functions:
 Formulate and implement Community forest management plans
 Develop annual work plans and budgets
 Buildcommunity level forest management capacity
 Provide technicalbackstoppingto community groups
 Promote local level forest-based enterprise development
 Implement forest protection and establishment activities - law enforcement, community
nursery establishment and management, fire management, and forest regeneration
management
 Provide support to community forest management groups in the implementation of
participatory forest management
 Work closely with legal bodies to enforce the law of the land in natural resources
management
 Promote cross-institutional collaboration by ensuring full participation of other key
government line agencies such as the agriculture, energy, local government, education,
wildlife, NGOs,etc.in project implementation

PROJECT DESCRIPTION
VCS Version 3, CCB Standards Second Edition
The Zambia Wildlife ActNo. 14 of 2015: This Act provides for the establishment, control, and
management of National Parks and the conservation and protection of wildlife and other objects
of aesthetic, pre-historical and scientific interest in National parks; to provide for the
establishment of game management areas; to provide for the licensing of hunting and the
control of the possession, transfer, sale and export and import of wild animal and trophies. This
Act isrelevant to the project as the area has wildlife populations in it.
In the process of implementing the Musokotwane REDD+ project compliance with all project-
related laws and acts will be observed. The implementation of the project activities will not lead
to the violation of any applicable laws of Zambia, regardless ofwhetheror notthe law is
enforced.
3.2 Evidence of Project Ownership(G5)
There are no explicit laws that exist on carbon ownership in Zambia. Under the Lands Act of
2005, customary tenure is recognized under section 7 (1). The local communities therefore,
have the full rights to environmental goods and services that include biomass and soils in
customary areas. Land is held in trust by the Chief on behalf of their subjects.
While no explicit carbon rights are established, the Town and Country Planning Act mandates
the traditional authorities (Chiefs) the right to “take measures for the conservation or
improvement of natural resources” (Section48) in their chiefdoms.
Therefore, the consent letter signed by Chief Musokotwane in the project area transfers the
carbon rights to theproject proponent. The consent establishes Musokotwane REDD+ Project
as the common project ofthe project proponent and the local communities in the Chiefdom. The
consent gives Zambruss Enterprise Ltd the rights to develop, establish and market the project
with support of the Musokotwane people. Copy of the consent is provided in this document as
annex II.
3.3 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits(CL1)

mandatorylimits or similar

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.7 Ownership
The project proponent meets the ownership requirements of the VCS Program specifications as detailed
in section 3.6 of the VCS Standard v4.3 Specifically, the project proponent has the legal right to control
and operate all project activities for the duration of the crediting period.
Specifically, ownership is demonstrated according to Clause 4 of the VCS Program Standard:
“Project ownership arising by virtue of a statutory, property or contractual right in the land, vegetation
or conservational or management process that generated GHG emission reductions and/or removals
(where the project proponent has not been divested of such project ownership).”
The project proponent, EcoPlanet Bamboo, through the subsidiary detailed in Section 1.6 above holds
the contractual right to the implement the proposed project activities, along with the associated
ownership of the GHG emission removals. This contractual right is evidenced by a Memorandum of
Understanding3 and a Letter of Authorization issued by the Rwanda Water Resources Board4.
Within the terms of this Agreement, EcoPlanet Bamboo holds the legal right to utilize carbon financing to
implement and operate the program activities, as well as to all and any GHG emission removals generated
by the project during the crediting period. These agreements are available to auditors as part of validation
and subsequent verification events.
1.8 Project Start Date
October 1st 2022
This date corresponds to the date of first planting.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
The proposed project crediting period is 20 years.
Start date: October 1st 2022
End date: September 30th 2042

{'project_name': 'Bohui Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation', 'project_summary': 'The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Bozhou District and Huichuan District, Guizhou Province, where located in southwestern China with a total acreage of 18,908 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the backward continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to production increase and methane emissions decrease than the continuously flooded.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir construction and necessary training for farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional flooded method. Controllable irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (flooded state) In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48% . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 3.17 tCO2e/ha for rice is expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 419,139 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 59,877 tCO2e.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes.
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers.
- Provide more job opportunities, especially female workers.
- Use a proportion of benefits to improve the local children’s education.', 'project_state_province': 'Guizhou', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 27.68, 'project_longitude': 106.78}

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Ecosystem type: The grouped project area is within mangrove ecosystems regions, a type of
wetland forest.
Current and historical land-use: Veracruz’s fertile soils and humid subtropical climate were
historically ideal for agricultural activities, particularly for coffee and sugar cane, despite the
relatively flat ground in some areas. As coffee price decreased in the middle of the 19th century,
much of the region’s flatter terrain was cleared for sugar plantation. The rise in population in the
region stimulated by a petroleum boom, in addition to land demand for cattle ranching, increased
pressure on limited land supply12.
Currently, the predominant land use is agriculture, citriculture and livestock, the latter being one
of the drivers of deforestation due to transformation into grasslands. According to the UNAM13,
the indicators of the physical arrangement allow us to infer that one of the most significant
problems of change in land use is the sedimentation of silt in coastal water bodies.

In the future, more project activity instances, inside state-owned, private or ejidos’ lands, will be added to this grouped project.

Conservation activities include, but are not limited to, reestablishing canals, maintaining canal structures, soil rehabilitation, deforestation monitoring, and monitoring of biodiversity.

The project proponent has been engaging with communities in ejidos and private lands since 2016 under a participatory and inclusive approach and will also include more properties as the project is developed.  BlueMX is also conducting capacity building sessions and developing outreach and communication materials to empower communities to carry out the conservation activities.

The grouped project totals 4,903 hectares of wetlands and is estimated to reduce approximately 65,946 t CO2e per year.

The Project area is not covered by any jurisdictional REDD+ program.

BlueMX is also designing the project for certifying climate, community, and biodiversity benefits under the CCB Programme.', 'project_state_province': 'Veracruz', 'project_country': 'Mexico', 'project_latitude': 19.33, 'project_longitude': -96.67}

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The “Improved cropland management project in Morin Dawa” is aimed to raise farmer's
awareness on the benefits of sustainable agriculture and how to change the agricultural practices
to help in climate change mitigation and adaptation. The project will assist farmers to overcome
barriers that prevent adoption of improved agricultural land management practices and provide
technical assistance where needed. The objectives of the project is to reduce emissions from
agricultural practices and increase soil carbon storage, in order to achieve these, a package of
practices that change the pre-existing agricultural management activities will be carried out, the
specific activities are the following:
A. Reduce fertilizer (organic or inorganic) application;
B. Reduce tillage/improve residue management; and
C. Improve crop planting and harvesting.
The project is developed as a grouped project within the boundary of Inner Mongolia. Thus, the
expansion of a project activity subsequent to project validation is allowed and each project activity
instance shall follow the program eligibility criteria for its inclusion as detailed in section 1.4. The
initial project activity instance is located in Morin Dawa Daur Autonomous Banner (hereinafter as
“Morin Dawa”), Inner Mongolia, where is in the north of China. The project activities includes
reducing fertilizer application, no tillage, and straw returning to improve residue management. It
also involves crop rotations of corns and soybeans to improve crop planting and harvesting. The
initial project activity instance will cover 61,333 ha located in Morin Dawa.
Prior to the start of the implementation of the project, there was no similar sequestration of
carbon, removals or net reduction of GHG activities. The baseline scenario is the continuation of
pre-project agricultural land management practices, which are common agricultural practices in
Inner Mongolia. The initial project activity instance will generate an estimated annual average
removal and reduction of 1,015,078 tCO2e. Over the 20 years of the first crediting period, the
project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions by 20,301,554 tCO2e in this period.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project falls under the sectoral scope 14: Agriculture, Forestry and other land use (AFOLU).
The category of the project is Agriculture Land Management (ALM). The project is a large and a
grouped project using the methodology VM0042 “Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land
Management”(version 1.0). The type of the project activity is improved cropland management
activity (ICM) since the practices involved in the project activity demonstrably reduce net GHG
emissions of cropland systems by increasing soil carbon stocks, reducing N O emissions, and/or 2

1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Prior to the project initiation, economic conditions in the project area are backward and the level
of education is relatively low, so farmers lack advanced irrigation technologies like intermittent
flooded water regime. However, the intermittent flooding system requires that the irrigation and
drainage be controlled according to the growth needs of the rice during the rice cultivation
process. In fact, the low economic level has led to low incomes of farmers, which means that
farmers do not have the additional economic capacity to build cement ditches with controlled
irrigation and drainage. Therefore, the project was not implemented to generate greenhouse gas
emissions for subsequent reduction, removal or destruction.
Since the conditions existing prior to the project initiation is the same as baseline scenario,
please refer to Section 3.4 (Baseline Scenario) to see the detail information. Besides, this project
does not affect the environmental conditions, including climate, hydrology, topography, soils,
relevant historical conditions, type of vegetation, ecosystems, etc., so, the present and prior
environmental conditions of this project are the same, which are listed as follows.

Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
The project activity includes cement ditch construction, reservoir construction and necessary training for the farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method. Controllable irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (flooded state). In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48%. Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 2.80 tCO2e/ha is expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 373,660 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 53,380 tCO2e.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes.
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers.
- Provide more job opportunities, especially female workers.
- Use a proportion of benefits to improve the local children’s education.', 'project_state_province': 'Guizhou Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 25.69, 'project_longitude': 106.38}

2.1.10 Sectoral scope and project type
The project comes under scope 14 in the AFOLU category of REDD, ‘Avoided Unplanned Deforestation
and Degradation’ (AUDD). The project is a grouped one that aims to set up a financing framework for
activities proposed by the NPCSA to protect and conserve the region's biodiversity. Specifically, the
project seeks to promote and improve activities in four strategic areas, such as ecotourism, scientific
research, fire prevention, and governance and administration. In addition, the project was designed under
the Climate, Community & Biodiversity Standards (Version 3).
2.1.11 Project activities and Theory of Change (G1.8)
The Serra do Amolar REDD+ project is not covered by a jurisdictional REDD+ program. Under the
direction of the IHP,77 the project aims to combine its efforts in relation to the conservation and
sustainability of the Pantanal as a biological corridor and source of well-being for its traditional
communities. To maximize its means and optimize the financial, technical and logistical resources in
partnership with the Ecotrópica Foundation and ICMBio, the REDD+ project has a gradual
implementation of activities following a technically-oriented strategic plan, based on the RPCSA lines.
The Serra do Amolar REDD+ project is subdivided into seven strategic lines which include interactions
between the IHP, local communities and other institutions in the Pantanal that have worked together to
achieve its conservation, constructing community and biodiversity objectives. These strategic lines will
provide stakeholders with an income flow to promote poverty reduction in associated communities,
especially as governance is strengthened, projects are implemented, and activities are developed for
Pantanal monitoring.
A description of each project activity – and the expected outputs, outcomes and impacts of each activity –
are presented in Table 16. Regarding the construction of the scopes by project activity, the Theory of
Change (ToC) approach was used to explain how these activities will achieve the expected benefits for
climate, community and biodiversity (CCB).
With the ToC analysis, it is concluded that project activities in their current situation (activities or initiatives
already implemented in the project area), with the help of the multiple institutions involved in the project,
will achieve their goals in the short (2016–2025), medium (2026–2035) and long term (2036–2045).
The strategic activities will be revised throughout the crediting period by the executive committee of IHP,
as more data becomes available about the necessary resources and the results of the implementation.
The following provides a detailed description of the project’s GHG emission reduction activities.

Strengthening area management aims to build technical, administrative and institutional capacities which
will promote new agreements and implement the best practices related to the protection of the Pantanal

CCB + VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
using CDM Afforestation/Reforestation Methodologies” and dated 8 March 2011.
3.1.2 Applicability of Methodology
The project activity is reforestation of lands that have not been cleared of native ecosystems for at
least 10 years prior to the project start date, which is within the scope of the methodology when
used for VCS28. The native ecosystem of the project area would be forest29 if not for a long history
of human-caused impacts to the area. Evidence that the project area was cleared of native
ecosystems more than 10 years ago is provided in Figure 3 and in more detail in Figure 15.
The VCS eligible planting areas shown in Figure 15 were mapped in a two-stage process. First,
July 2013 Landsat 8 data was classified as either forest or non-forest using training areas and
randomforest. Then non-forest polygon boundaries within the proposed planting area were
adjusted by hand to align with Google Earth high resolution imagery from 2009-2012. For a small
portion of the area not covered in Google Earth, Bing imagery was used after it was established
that the Bing imagery was also from 2012 by comparing the location of farms in the parts that
overlapped with Google Earth. The mapped non-forest areas were overlayed on Sentinel-2 data
from July 2021 to look for any evidence of reforestation. No natural regeneration was found. A
couple planted pine plots were found, which were used as a basis for adjusting the planting area
boundaries to avoid all areas with potential for pine planting (see Figure 11).
In addition to the mapping described above, a point-based sample of land-cover was conducted.
One hundred random points were generated within the project area polygon boundaries. The land-
cover was interpreted for 2012 using sub-meter Google Earth and Bing imagery and for 2021 using
Sentinel-2 imagery from July, August and Planet.com base maps from June and July. From the
2012 high resolution imagery, three land covers were identified; herbaceous thicket dominated by
bracken ferns, active farm, and herbaceous thicket with scattered trees not meeting the definition
of forest. Most of the trees in the latter class were so small that they were not clearly visible in 2021
since the highest resolution data available was 4-meter Planet.com basemaps. Not a single point
fell into an area with trees that would add up to a patch of forest more than 0.5 ha, which is the
minimum area threshold for forest in Tanzania. The results (Figure 5) show little change apart from
a statistically insignificant increase in the proportion under active farms.
Figure 5. Results of land-cover point assessment
28 CDM requires that A/R project areas be non-forest since 1989, but the document “AFOLU Guidance: Additional
guidance for VCS Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation projects using CDM Afforestation/Reforestation
Methodologies” provided by Verra clarifies that the VCS standard supersedes this requirement for A/R projects
validated under VCS. Currently, the VCS standard requires that A/R project areas cannot have been cleared of native
ecosystems for at least 10 years prior to the start date.
29 The Tanzanian definition of forest is 10% canopy cover of trees with a minimum height of 3 meters over an area at
least 0.5 ha.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1. PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project activity consists of promoting fuel switching in the operation of Nexa Recursos
Minerais S.A., a metallurgical company, which is primarily geared towards zinc production,
located in the municipality of Três Marias, in the State of Minas Gerais. The fuel switching has
been carried out by Combio Energia S.A., a company whose main activity is the production and
distribution of steam, hot water and air conditioning.
Founded in 1969, Nexa’s Três Marias unit, formerly Votorantim metals, is the main metallurgical
company that carries out the processing of zinc in Brazil. In 2017, the company was responsible
for the production of 186 thousand tons of zinc. Since its initiation, Nexa has utilized BPF oil to
steam generation.
On 02-October-2015 Nexa signed a contract with Combio in which Combio would generate and
provide the steam necessary to the zinc processing. Combio started operating inside the Nexa
industry on 06-March-2017 commercializing steam generated at the hybrid boiler (flamotubular
and aquatubular) using renewable biomass as fuel, which defined the project start date.
The implementation of this project activity has the objective of drastically reduce the use of BPF
oil and substitutes it with renewable biomass to generate steam to sustain Nexa’s production, with
the intention of minimizing environmental impacts including the reduction of Greenhouse Gases
(GHG) emissions.
The switching of fossil fuel to renewable biomass is expected to reduce an average of 58,519
tCO e per year during the first crediting period of the project. Therefore, GHG emission 2
reductions equate to around 585,189 tCO e over the 10 years project crediting period. 2

scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario.
Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of
methane (CH ) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is 4
more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction
than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH emission 4
can be declined by an average of 48%1 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.47 tCO e/ha for single-cropping rice is 2
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 55,884 tCO e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 558,840 tCO e during the 2 2
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.

(AFOLU)” with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Prior to the project initiation, the farmers use predominant traditional rice cultivation method
which is traditional practice with continuously flooded fields. This condition continues because
of economic conditions of the farmers as well as lack of knowledge regarding advanced
irrigation technologies like intermittent flooded water regime. Intermittent flooded water regime
requires that irrigation and drainage can be controlled according to the growth needs of rice
during its cultivation.
This project was implemented for farmers to practice the intermittent flooded water regime,
thus increasing the rice yield and promoting agricultural sustainable development.
Since the conditions existing prior to the project initiation is the same as baseline scenario,
please refer to Section 3.4 (Baseline Scenario) of the PD to see the detail information. Besides,
this project does not affect the environmental conditions, including climate, hydrology,
topography, soils, relevant historical conditions, type of vegetation, ecosystems, etc., so, the
present and prior environmental conditions of this project are the same, which are listed below.

The main objective of the project is to switch from continuously flooded rice fields to fields that alternately encompass flooded and non-flooded phases which can save significant amount of irrigation water. Thus, the project activity has been designed to change from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation which is conducted in different blocks in the district of Bhopal, Hoshangabad, Raisen and Sehore of the state of Madhya Pradesh, in India. A total of 8,085 hectare for single-cropping rice has been covered under the project activity. During rice cultivation, controllable irrigation and drainage according to rice growth requirements can save water resources, and also at the same time will also reduce methane emission from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (in the flooded state). Additionally, in the project activity compost will be used for soil application in the rice fields and thus replace the application of synthetic nitrogen fertilizer. It is estimated that about 58,722 tCO2e emission reductions will be generated annually across the crediting period.", 'project_state_province': 'Madhya Pradesh', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 22.76, 'project_longitude': 78.51}

1.13 Project Location
The Balanga village, part of the Bena Kamanya sector, which has about 100,000 inhabitants
distributed and 25 groups is about 40 km south-west of the city of Moba, capital of the territory in
the East of the Democratic Republic of Congo.
The territory of Moba is separated from Tanzania by Lake Tanganyika to the east and shares its

VCS Project Description Template, v4.3

1.14 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
This project is located in the territory of Moba, is a capital locality of the province of Tanganyika in
the Democratic Republic of Congo. It extends to the south of the province of Tanganyika in the east
of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Moba is separated from Tanzania by Lake Tanganyika to the
east, the territory of Kalemie is located to the north and Moba shares its boundaries with Manono
and Pweto. The territory is known for its mountainous landscape, its fauna and flora resources and
its strategic position.
Agriculture is a significant source of livelihood for the people of Moba. Subsistence farming, with
crops like cassava, maize, and groundnuts, is common. Fishing plays a crucial role in the local
economy, given Lake Tanganyika's presence. Fish from the lake is a vital source of protein for the
population.
Infrastructure in the project and surrounding areas are limited and poorly maintained, including roads
and transportation networks. Access to basic services such as healthcare and education are also
limited. Poverty rates in rural areas of the DRC, including Moba, are high. Lack of economic
opportunities, limited access to education, and healthcare challenges contribute to the cycle of
poverty.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The Cevizlik Hydroelectric Power Plant reduces greenhouse gas emissions that would have
otherwise occurred in the absence of the project activity by avoiding electricity generation from
fossil fuel sources both in the operating margin and build margin of the system. The average
annual emission reductions of the proposed project are estimated to be, 162,665 tonnes of CO e 2
(tCO e). 2
1.14 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
The applicable mandatory laws that have been applied for the project are:
1. Electricity Market Law No:64465: This Law aims to ensure the development of a financially
sound and transparent electricity market operating in a competitive environment under the
provisions of civil law. It also underlines the need to produce sufficient, high quality, low cost,
and environmentally friendly electricity to consumers. The text also provides guidelines to
structure the autonomous regulation and the supervision of the market.
2. Law on Utilization of Renewable Energy Resources for the Purpose of Generating Electrical
Energy6: The purpose of this law is to expand the utilization of renewable energy sources for
generating electric energy, to benefit from these resources in a secure, economic, and
qualified manner, to increase the diversification of energy resources, to reduce greenhouse
gas emissions, to assess waste products, to protect the environment and to develop the
related manufacturing industries for realizing these objectives.
3. Environmental Law7: This law came into force in 1983, it considers the environment as a
single domain, aiming not only to prevent and eliminate environmental pollution but also to
allow the management of land and natural resources in an integrated manner. According to
its basic principles, and as also stated in the Constitution, citizens as well as the State bear
responsibility for environmental protection.
The project complies with all aforementioned laws as its activity aims at generating electricity by using a
renewable resource: hydroelectric power; in a sufficient, low-cost, and environmentally friendly manner,
using the latest technology available on the market. Moreover, an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA)
had been carried out and the results of this study concluded that the project activity has no significant
impacts on the environment.
Additionally, according to the letter from the Trabzon Regional Forestry Directorate Forest Operation
Management, dated March 27th, 2006, the project activity would supply added values and employment,
and consider the negative impact on the forest and its vicinities.
Furthermore, in the official letter from the Ministry of Culture and Tourism, Trabzon Regional Council of
Protection of Cultural and Natural Assets, dated May 26th, 2005, it was declared that there are not any
cultural or historical assets in the Project site as defined within the scope of the Laws No: 3386, 5226
and 2863.

The plant has been designed to generate electricity by utilizing the 230 m of head between the tailwater level of the upstream existing Ikizdere HEPP and the Kalkandere HEPP project. The project activity is the biggest size run-off-river project ever realised in Turkey considering its installed capacity and first of its kind as it is constructed underground without any upstream reservoir lake.The main purpose of the project is to generate approximately 335 GWh/year of electricity to supply the national grid using a renewable resource and tapping the significant hydropower potential in the region. The project activity reduces greenhouse gases (GHGs) emissions that would have otherwise occurred in the absence of the project activity by avoiding electricity generation from fossil fuel sources. The environmental impact assessment report for this project was carried out by in 01/2011. The results of

A summary of conclusion of the report is illustrated as below:
Ambient air
The impact on ambient air quality of the proposed project is mainly from dust during construction stage.
The excavation work is the primary emission source, however, it is a ground source and the particle size
is quite large so that dust will deposit quickly on the ground. Immediately replant the areas where
construction has completed, and by sprinkling water frequently and timely clearing can reduce the dust
pollution. When the project is in operational period, there will be no air pollutions. In conclusion, the
proposed project will not pose any threat on the quality of ambient air.

The project crediting period for the project activity will be 10 years. Options to re-validate the

1.7 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
Unlike traditional utility scale projects that hope to utilize biomass for process heat or electricity
based on 365 day a year operations, Metrolina’s heating needs are seasonal and are directly
related to the interaction between optimum growing environment temperature and the outside
temperature. Greenhouse growers of this scale and location utilize most of their heat during the
winter months, mainly October through May or approximately 36 weeks.
Based on historical natural gas usage information and capacity of the biomass boiler system, the
project activity could realize up to 25,000 tCO2e annually and therefore qualifies as “project”
scale category. Table 1 below shows the estimated emission reductions from the project over the
entire crediting period using ex ante calculations. However, due to the direct relationship between
thermal energy use/need, and the temperature outside the growing environment, actual emission
reductions will vary year to year.
A spreadsheet is provided estimating these ex-ante emission reductions8.

1.18 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
As per VCS Standard v4.5, the projects are encouraged to include leakage management zones
as part of the overall project design. Leakage management zones are part of a leakage
management plan, they can minimize the displacement of land use activities to areas outside
the project area by maintaining the production of goods and services, such as agricultural
products, within areas under the control of the Project Proponent or by addressing the socio-
economic factors that drive land use change. As per section 3.15.15 of VCS Standard v4.5, the
projects will monitor and calculate leakage, by the applied methodology, for all ex-post accounting
(i.e., at each verification), and leakage shall be deducted from the GHG emission reductions
and/or carbon dioxide removals of the project. Any leakage shall be subtracted from the number
of reductions and removals eligible to be issued as VCUs.
The project's overall leakage has been deemed negligible, as the displacement of agricultural
activities can be considered insignificant.

The Fujian Pucheng Improved Forest Management Project (hereafter “the project activity”)

county, Liantang county, Linjiang county, Nanpu county, Panting county, Shanxia county,

involved in the project are Masson Pine, Chinese Fir and Hard Broad-Leaved tree.

verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area.

the GHG emissions for about 2,091,955 tCO e in 30 years, the average annual emission 2

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
2.2 Local Stakeholder Consultation
In order to assess the adequacy of the local stakeholder consultation the Project Proponent
informed all the local stakeholders relevant for the project activity. The stakeholders are:
• Employees of the company
• Cooperation partners of the company
• Landlords
• Residents
• Local representatives from the government
• Other persons with socially relevant positions (such teachers, priests, hunters)
• Neighbouring farmers
The local stakeholder consultation was held on 08 December 2021. Invitations were sent by
postal letters and by e-mails. A detailed list of invitations was given to the VVB. In addition, a
public notice was posted at the local bus stop so that people who did not receive a personal
invitation could attend.
It was originally planned to hold an event in presence, showing the fields of the farm and
explaining the planned project activities on site. However, due to the devastating Covid-19
situation in the winter of 2021 in Germany, such an event was not possible. Therefore, the local
stakeholder consultation was conducted online. After an introduction of all Project Proponents,
detailed information was provided on the impact of climate change on local agriculture, the
relevance of humus and the planned project activities. Great care was taken to ensure that the
topics were presented in such a way that they could be understood by people without in-depth
expertise as well as those with specialist knowledge. Afterwards, the attendees were invited to
ask questions and discuss with the Project Proponents. Among other things, the planned
measures and financial challenges for farmers were discussed. Overall, the project received a lot
of interest from the attendees and did not earn any negative comments.
To ensure ongoing communication, an email address was established for stakeholders to report
comments, requests or grievances. It was explicitly stated that any feedback is welcome.
2.3 Environmental Impact
The project activity is designed to reduce the negative impact of agricultural activities on nature
and climate. The applied regenerative practices aim at restoring and maintaining soil health and
fertility, support biodiversity, protect watersheds, and improve ecological and economic
resilience. By re-carbonizing soils via photosynthesis and biology, particularly on degraded land,
